user_facing_answer.text:
Hello! PharmaMiku here! 🌟 While this isn't a medical question, I'll help explain what we know about the name Parthiv in a clear way! ✨

Name Meaning & Origin:
• Parthiv comes from Sanskrit "pārthiva" 
• It beautifully means "son of the earth" or "prince of earth"
• It's a Hindu/Indian boy's name with royal associations

Cultural Significance:
• Associated with positive qualities like:
  • Bravery
  • Leadership
  • Noble characteristics
• Connected to Hindu astrology:
  • Rashi (Zodiac): Kanya/Virgo
  • Nakshatra (Birth Star): Uttara Phalguni
  • Lucky number: 4

Famous Person:
• Parthiv Patel is the most well-known person with this name:
  • Former Indian cricket player (2002-2018)
  • Made history as youngest Test wicket-keeper at age 17
  • Now works as cricket commentator
  • Recently became assistant/batting coach for Gujarat Titans

Current Usage:
• Still used in India and Hindu communities
• Considered relatively uncommon (rank ~7322)
• Valued for its meaningful connection to earth and leadership

Learn More! 📚
For more information, you can check these sources:
• https://www.ask-oracle.com/baby-name/parthiv/
• https://mylofamily.com/parenting/babynames/meaning-of-parthiv-60619
• https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiva
• https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthiv_Patel

Based on the provided evidence, here is what we know about Parthiv:

Name Meaning and Origin:
- Parthiv is a Hindu/Indian boy's name that means "son of the earth" or "prince of earth"
- It originates from Sanskrit "pārthiva" meaning "earthly" or "related to earth"
- The name has associations with being brave, earthly, and princely

Notable Person:
- Parthiv Patel (born 1985) is a well-known former Indian cricketer who played as a wicket-keeper batsman for the Indian national cricket team from 2002-2018
- He became the youngest wicket-keeper to represent a country in Tests when he debuted at age 17
- After retiring in 2020, he became a cricket commentator and recently was appointed as assistant/batting coach for Gujarat Titans

Religious/Cultural Context:
- It is a Hindu name associated with:
  - Rashi (Zodiac): Kanya/Virgo 
  - Nakshatra (Birth Star): Uttara Phalguni
  - Lucky number: 4

The name Parthiv remains in use in India and Hindu communities, though it is considered relatively uncommon (popularity rank around 7322). The name carries connotations of being connected to the earth, having leadership qualities, and possessing royal/noble characteristics according to Hindu traditions.

So in summary, Parthiv is a meaningful Hindu boy's name with royal and earthy associations, most famously held by the Indian cricket player Parthiv Patel in recent times.

evidence.title: Parthiva, Pārthiva: 27 definitions
evidence.content: # Parthiva, Pārthiva: 27 definitions 1. [Introduction](#introduction) 2. [In Hinduism](#hinduism) Purana Natyashastra Jyotisha Ayurveda Shaktism 3. [In Buddhism](#buddhism) Tibetan Buddhism 4. [Languages](#language) Marathi Sanskrit Hindi Kannada Nepali 5. [See also](#relevant-definitions) ## Introduction: Parthiva means something in [Buddhism](https://www.wisdomlib.org/buddhism), Pali, [Hinduism](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism), Sanskrit, Marathi, Hindi. If you want to know the exact meaning, history, etymology or English translation of this term then check out the descriptions on this page. Add your comment or reference to a book if you want to contribute to this summary article. Alternative spellings of this word include [Parthiv](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiv). ## In Hinduism ### Purana and Itihasa (epic history) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Purana glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to “earthen”, representing the material of the liṅgas of the Aśvinidevas, according to the [Śivapurāṇa 2.1.12](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/shiva-purana-english/d/doc225980.html), where the Devas and Viṣṇu requested Viśvakarman for liṅgas for the achievement of the desires of all people:—“[...] at our bidding Viśvakarmā made liṅgas and gave them to the devas according to their status. [...] The Viśvedevas and the Vasus took silver liṅgas. O sage, the Aśvini devas took the brazen and earthen liṅgas (Pārthiva-liṅga). [...] Thus different kinds of liṅgas were given to them by Viśvakarmā which the devas and the celestial sages worship regularly. After giving the devas the various liṅgas from a desire for their benefit, Viṣṇu explained the mode of worship of Śiva to me, Brahmā”. 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to “clay”, representing a material for a Liṅga in one’s house (*geha*), according to the [Śivapurāṇa 2.1.13](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/shiva-purana-english/d/doc225981.html), while explaining the mode of worshipping Śiva:—“[...] after worshipping Śiva with sandal paste, saffron, incense, various lamps, and food-offerings of different sorts he shall bow down again. In the house the liṅga shall be made of clay (*pārthiva*), silver or any other metal or mercury. It shall be bowed to with devotion. If that is worshipped, all deities are worshipped. If the liṅga is made of clay it shall be installed duly”. [Source](https://archive.org/details/SivaPuranaJ.L.ShastriPart1): archive.org: Shiva Purana - English Translation 1a) Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—An Ārṣeya Pravara.* - [*](#text1_1) Matsya-purāṇa 196. 9. 1b) One of the three fires; it was so called when (1/4) of the night of Brahmā was remaining.* - [*](#text2_1) Vāyu-purāṇa 53. 5-7. 1c) Also Pavana; a kind of fire.* - [*](#text3_1) Brahmāṇḍa-purāṇa II. 24. 6. 1d) Of Kauśika gotra.* - [*](#text4_1) Vāyu-purāṇa 91. 98. [Source](http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PUIScan/2014/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: The Purana Index The Purana (पुराण, purāṇas) refers to Sanskrit literature preserving ancient India’s vast cultural history, including historical legends, religious ceremonies, various arts and sciences. The eighteen *mahapuranas* total over 400,000 *shlokas* (metrical couplets) and date to at least several centuries BCE. ### Natyashastra (theatrics and dramaturgy) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Natyashastra glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to a “king” (or, “lord of the earth”), whose beard (*śmaśru*) should be represented as *vicitra* (smartly done), according to [Nāṭyaśāstra chapter 23](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/the-natyashastra/d/doc210153.html). Providing the beard is a component of *nepathya* (costumes and make-up) and is to be done in accordance with the science of *āhāryābhinaya* (extraneous representation). [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Nāṭya-śāstra Natyashastra (नाट्यशास्त्र, *nāṭyaśāstra*) refers to both the ancient Indian tradition (*shastra*) of performing arts, (*natya*—theatrics, drama, dance, music), as well as the name of a Sanskrit work dealing with these subjects. It also teaches the rules for composing Dramatic plays (*nataka*), construction and performance of Theater, and Poetic works (*kavya*). ### Jyotisha (astronomy and astrology) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Jyotisha glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the “ruler” (of a kingdom), according to the [Bṛhatsaṃhitā (chapter 4)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita/d/doc226720.html), an encyclopedic Sanskrit work written by Varāhamihira mainly focusing on the science of ancient Indian astronomy astronomy (Jyotiṣa).—Accordingly, “If Jupiter should be eclipsed by the lunar disc the men of Gāndhāra, of Sauvīraka, of Sindhu and of Kīra (Kāśmīra) the rulers of the Draviḍa countries and Brāhmins as well as food grains and mountains will suffer for ten months. If Mars should be so eclipsed the rulers of Traigarta (Lāhora) and of Mālavā, with their fighting men in their cars, the chiefs of Kulinda, the rulers [i.e., *pārthiva*] of Śibi, of Audha, of Kuru (Delhi), of Matsya and of Śukti will suffer for six months”. 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the nineteenth of the sixty-year cycle of Jupiter, according to the [Bṛhatsaṃhitā (chapter 8)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita/d/doc226724.html).—Accordingly, “The first year of the fourth *yuga* is known as Citrabhānu; in it mankind will be happy. The second is known as Subhānu. In it mankind will be neither happy nor miserable; there will however be disease in the land but no deaths in consequence. The next year is known as Tāraṇa; in it there will be abundance of rain. The next is known as Pārthiva; in it crops with thrive well and mankind will be happy. The fifth year is known as Vyaya; in it amorous sensastions will prevail over the land”. [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita): Wisdom Library: Brihat Samhita by Varahamihira Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the nineteenth [saṃvatsara (“jovian year)”](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/samvatsara) in Vedic astrology.—The native born in the ‘*samvatsara*’ of ‘*parthiva*’ performs the rites of his religion (with reverence), is well versed (learned) in the excellent *shastras*, is a perfected hand (skilled) in the field of arts, sensual or pleasure-loving and is the chief of his family. According with Jataka Parijata, the person born in the year *parthiva* (2005-2006 AD) will be a king unequalled for his prosperity and happiness. [Source](http://satva.blogspot.nl/2011/12/effects-of-samvatsaras.html): The effect of Samvatsaras: Satvargas Jyotisha (ज्योतिष, *jyotiṣa* or *jyotish*) refers to ‘astronomy’ or “Vedic astrology” and represents the fifth of the six Vedangas (additional sciences to be studied along with the Vedas). Jyotisha concerns itself with the study and prediction of the movements of celestial bodies, in order to calculate the auspicious time for rituals and ceremonies. ### Ayurveda (science of life) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Ayurveda glossary #### Nighantu (Synonyms and Characteristics of Drugs and technical terms) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) or Pārthivakṣetra refers to “earthen land” and represents one of the five classifications of [“land” (kṣetra)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/\), as defined in the first chapter (*ānūpādi-varga*) of the 13th-century Raj Nighantu or Rājanighaṇṭu (an Ayurvedic encyclopedia). Accordingly, “a *pārthiva* or earther land is usually four-cornered, symmetrical. t has yellowish story ground with bracelet like shining, rounded gravels and is full of yellow coloured dear heards and creepers with yellow flowers. It is a hard and raised land”. Substances (*dravya*) pertaining to Pārthiva-kṣetra are known as Pārthivadravya—Such *dravyas* alleviate diseases and enhance vitality. These are tasty and have steady effect. Brāhma is the deity of Pārthiva soil and substances. [Source](https://www.worldcat.org/title/raj-nighantu/oclc/826899360): WorldCat: Rāj nighaṇṭu #### Veterinary Medicine (The study and treatment of Animals) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to a “king”, according to the 15th century [Mātaṅgalīlā](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/matangalila#ayurveda) composed by Nīlakaṇṭha in 263 Sanskrit verses, dealing with elephantology in ancient India, focusing on the science of management and treatment of elephants.—[Cf. chapter 2, “on favorable marks”]: “6. With very glossy, shining eyes, and reddish trunk ends, with rod-like penis handsome with the beauty of mango shoots, radiant as red lotuses, with voice like the koil’s; such elephants, assuredly, are auspicious for kings (*pārthiva*) [*gajāḥ śubhakarāḥ khalu pārthivānām*]”. [Source](https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.217383): archive.org: The Elephant Lore of the Hindus #### Unclassified Ayurveda definitions 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—One of the category of substances that are of mineral origin like silver, gold, etc. 2) [pārthivam] The substance predominently made of prithvi mahabhuta [Source](https://www.gurumukhi.ru/ayurveda/dictionary.aspx): gurumukhi.ru: Ayurveda glossary of terms Āyurveda (आयुर्वेद, ayurveda) is a branch of Indian science dealing with medicine, herbalism, taxology, anatomy, surgery, alchemy and related topics. Traditional practice of Āyurveda in ancient India dates back to at least the first millenium BC. Literature is commonly written in Sanskrit using various poetic metres. ### Shaktism (Shakta philosophy) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Shaktism glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the “whole earth”, according to the Manthānabhairavatantra, a vast sprawling work that belongs to a corpus of Tantric texts concerned with the worship of the goddess Kubjikā.—Accordingly, “If a conflagration without a fire (that starts it) begins suddenly in a village, the offering of beef into the Triangle with clarified butter a million times (brings about) great peace and that prevails over the whole earth [i.e., *pārthiva*]”. 2) Pārthivā (पार्थिवा) refers to one of the eight Yoginīs (*yoginī-aṣṭaka*) associated with Kāmākhya (corresponding to the eastern face of Bhairava), according to the Manthānabhairavatantra.—[...] The eight Yoginīs (*yoginyaṣṭaka*): Viśālā, Pārthivā, Yakṣī, Dhūrjaṭī, Viṣabhakṣaṇī, Sarvasiddhipradā, Tuṣṭi, Icchā, Siddhipradāyakī. [Source](https://books.google.com/books?id=2DhazgEACAAJ): Google Books: Manthanabhairavatantram Shakta (शाक्त, śākta) or Shaktism (śāktism) represents a tradition of Hinduism where the Goddess (Devi) is revered and worshipped. Shakta literature includes a range of scriptures, including various Agamas and Tantras, although its roots may be traced back to the Vedas. ## In Buddhism ### Tibetan Buddhism (Vajrayana or tantric Buddhism) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Tibetan Buddhism glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to one of the “[Twenty-Five Kalkis](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/twenty-five-lineage-holders#tibetan-buddhism)” (Tibetan: *rigs ldan*) as well as the “[Thirty-two kings of Shambhala](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/thirty-two-kings-of-shambhala#tibetan-buddhism)”, according to the Tibetan oral recounting and written texts such as the Kalachakra Tantra (*kālacakratantra*), dealing with the Buddhist conception of the end of the world and time.—The Tibetan mythic land (the kingdom of Shambhala) is a parallel world invisible and inaccessible to common people which is closely related to the teaching about the Wheel of Time (*dus 'khor*). The seven Dharmarajas and twenty-five Kulikas [e.g., Pārthiva] are the traditional rulers of Shambhala, passing on the reign from father to son. Pārthiva is also known as Śrīpāla or Mahīpāla. He is known in Tibetan as (1) Sakyong (2) Rigden Sakyong [*rigs ldan sa skyong*] (3) [*sa skyong*] (4) [*sa bdag*] and in Mongolian as: Khaan Namninmiey. His traditional reign is considered to be from 1427 to 1527 CE. [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Tibetan Buddhist Teachers, Deities and other Spiritual beings Pārthiva (पार्थिव) is the name of the [tree (vṛkṣa)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/vriksha) associated with [Kilakilārava](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/kilakilarava#tibetan-buddhism): the north-western [cremation ground (śmaśāna)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/shmashana#tibetan-buddhism) according to the Saṃvarodayatantra 17.38. The tree associated with the north-west is sometimes given as Arjuna or Dhanañjaya. As a part of this *sādhana*, the practicioner is to visualize a suitable dwelling place for the goddess inside the circle of protection which takes the form of eight cremation grounds. These trees (e.g., Pārthiva) that are associated with the cremation grounds are often equated with the eight *bodhi*-trees of the Buddhas (the current *buddha* plus the seven previous one). According to the Śmaśānavidhi each tree has a secondary tree (*upavṛkṣa*) that is depicted as lovely and covered in *vaṅga* flowers and fruit. In each tree lives a naked *rākṣasa* who is wrathful in form, who eats human flesh and who has the animal face or the mount of the *dikpati* in his cremation ground. [Source](http://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Vajrayogini Pārthiva (पार्थिव) (in Tibetan: *Sakyong*) (1427–1527 CE) refers to the sixteenth of the twenty-five Kalki kings (of Shambhala) who represents the holders of the Kalachakra (“wheel of time”) teachings of Buddha Shakyamuni.—The king Pārthiva is described as “holder of the cleaver that cuts the bonds of ignorance”. [Source](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tibetan_Buddhism): WikiPedia: Tibetan Buddhism Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to one of the eight trees (*vṛkṣa*) of the [Guṇacakra](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/gunacakra#tibetan-buddhism), according to the 10th century [Ḍākārṇava](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/dakarnava#buddhism) chapter 15. Accordingly, the *guṇacakra* refers to one of the four divisions of the [sahaja-puṭa (‘innate layer’)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/sahaja#tibetan-buddhism), situated within the *padma* (lotus) in the middle of the [Herukamaṇḍala](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/herukamandala#buddhism). Pārthiva is associated with the charnel grounds (*śmaśāna*) named Kilikilārava; with the direction-guardian (*dikpāla*) named Vāyu; with the serpent king (*nāgendra*) named Śaṅkhapāla and with the cloud king (*meghendra*) named Caṇḍa. [Source](https://www.academia.edu/43250318/The_Structure_and_Meanings_of_the_Heruka_Ma%E1%B9%87%E1%B8%8Dala_in_the_Buddhist_%E1%B8%8C%C4%81k%C4%81r%E1%B9%87ava_Scriptural_Tradition): academia.edu: The Structure and Meanings of the Heruka Maṇḍala Tibetan Buddhism includes schools such as Nyingma, Kadampa, Kagyu and Gelug. Their primary canon of literature is divided in two broad categories: The Kangyur, which consists of Buddha’s words, and the Tengyur, which includes commentaries from various sources. Esotericism and tantra techniques (*vajrayāna*) are collected indepently. ## Languages of India and abroad ### Marathi-English dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Marathi glossary pārthiva (पार्थिव).—n S An earthen lingam made to use in worship. 2 m A king. --- OR --- pārthiva (पार्थिव).—a S Relating to earth, earthy or earthen. 2 Relating to the globe, terrene or terrestrial. [Source](http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/molesworth/): DDSA: The Molesworth Marathi and English Dictionary pārthiva (पार्थिव).—*n* An earthen lingam made to use in worship. *m* A king. *a* Relating to earth. Terrestrial. [Source](http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/vaze/): DDSA: The Aryabhusan school dictionary, Marathi-English Marathi is an Indo-European language having over 70 million native speakers people in (predominantly) Maharashtra India. Marathi, like many other Indo-Aryan languages, evolved from early forms of Prakrit, which itself is a subset of Sanskrit, one of the most ancient languages of the world. ### Sanskrit dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Sanskrit glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—*a.* (-vī *f.*) [पृथिव्याः ईश्वरः इदं वा अण् (pṛthivyāḥ īśvaraḥ idaṃ vā aṇ)] 1) Earthen, earthy, terrestrial, relating to the earth; यतो रजः पार्थिवमुज्जिहीते (yato rajaḥ pārthivamujjihīte) R.13.64. 2) Ruling the earth. 3) Princely, royal. -vaḥ 1 An inhabitant of the earth. 2) A king, sovereign; अथ तस्य विवाहकौतुकं ललितं बिभ्रत एव पार्थिवः (atha tasya vivāhakautukaṃ lalitaṃ bibhrata eva pārthivaḥ) R.8.1. 3) An earthen vessel. 4) The body. 5) The विकार (vikāra) of the earth; अयं जनो नाम चलन् पृथिव्यां यः पार्थिवः पार्थिव कस्य हेतोः (ayaṃ jano nāma calan pṛthivyāṃ yaḥ pārthivaḥ pārthiva kasya hetoḥ) Bhāgavata 5.12.5. 6) A गृह्याग्नि (gṛhyāgni) of the naming ceremony (*nāmakaraṇa*). -vam An earthy substance. -vā 1 A royal concubine. 2) Arsenic (see *nighaṇṭaratnākara*). [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/apte/): DDSA: The practical Sanskrit-English dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—mfn. (*-vaḥ-vā* or *vī-vaṃ*) 1. Earthen, made or derived from earth. 2. Ruling or possessing the earth. 3. Princely, royal. m. (*-vaḥ*) 1. A king, a prince. 2. An earthen vessel. 3. An inhabitant of the earth. f. (*-vī*) 1. A name of Sita. 2. An epithet of Lakshmi. E. *pṛthivī* the earth, *aṇ* aff. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/SHSScan/2014/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Shabda-Sagara Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—i. e. *pṛthivī + a*, I. adj., f. *vī*. 1. Terrestrial, Chr. 290, 3 = [Rigveda.] i. 64, 3 (vā for vāni). 2. Ruling or possessing the earth, Chr. 14, 17. 3. Royal, fit for kings or princes, Mahābhārata 5, 2187. Ii. m. 1. An inhabitant of the earth, [Rāmāyaṇa] 2, 25, 20. 2. A king, a prince. Iii. f. vī, Sītā. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/BENScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Benfey Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—1. [feminine] *ī* earthly, terrestrial; [masculine] inhabitant of the earth, lord of the earth, prince, king, warrior. Abstr. *tā*† [feminine], *tva*† [neuter] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—2. [feminine] *ī* royal, princely. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/CAEScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Cappeller Sanskrit-English Dictionary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—[from *pārthava*] mf(*ī* or *ā*; cf. [Pāṇini 4-1, 85], [vArttika] 2)n. ([from] *pṛthivī* f. of *pṛthu*) earthen, earthy, earthly, being in or relating to or coming from the earth, terrestrial, [Ṛg-veda] etc. etc. 2) [v.s. ...] mf(*ī*)n. (from m. below) fit for kings or princes, royal, princely, [Mahābhārata; Harivaṃśa] 3) [v.s. ...] m. an inhabitant of the earth, [Ṛg-veda; Atharva-veda] 4) [v.s. ...] a lord of the earth, king, prince, warrior, [Manu-smṛti; Mahābhārata] etc. 5) [v.s. ...] an earthen vessel, [cf. Lexicographers, esp. such as amarasiṃha, halāyudha, hemacandra, etc.] 6) [v.s. ...] a [particular] Agni, [Gṛhyāsaṃgraha] 7) [v.s. ...] the 19th (or 53rd) year in Jupiter’s cycle of 60 years, [Varāha-mihira] 8) [v.s. ...] ([plural]) Name of a family belonging to the Kauśikas, [Harivaṃśa] 9) [from *pārthava*] n. ([plural]) the regions of the earth, [Ṛg-veda] 10) [v.s. ...] an earthy substance, [Harivaṃśa] ([varia lectio] *thavi*), [Suśruta] 11) [v.s. ...] Tabernaemontana Coronaria, [cf. Lexicographers, esp. such as amarasiṃha, halāyudha, hemacandra, etc.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Monier-Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—*(vaḥ)* 1. *m.* A king; earthen vessel. *f.* (*vī*) *Sītā. a.* Earthen. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/YATScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Yates Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव):— --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. (von 1. *pārthiva* 2, b) adj. f. *ī* Fürsten zukommend, ihnen gehörend, fürstlich, königlich: *senā* [Mahābhārata 5, 2187.] *pravṛtti* [Sāvitryupākhyāna 6, 18.] *vartman* [Harivaṃśa 5462.] *pada* [5671.] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—1. 2) d) [Oxforder Handschriften 331,b,3 v. u.] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. , *kṣatra* [Mahābhārata 5, 6069.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PWGScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Böhtlingk and Roth Grosses Petersburger Wörterbuch Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—1. — 1) Adj. (f. *ā* und *ī*) irdisch , auf oder in der Erde befindlich , auf die E. bezüglich , der E eigen , aus E. entstanden , irden. *vrata* n. die Weise der Erde. — 2) m. — a) Erdbewohner. — b) Fürst , Krieger , König. — c) ein best. Agni. — d) *ein irdenes Geschirr. — e) das 19te (53ste) Jahr im 60jährigen Jupitercyclus. — f) Metron. Pl. auch als Name eines zu den Kauśika gezählten Geschlechts [Harivaṃśa 1464.1771.] — 3) f. *pārthivī* Metron. — a) der Sitā. — b) *der Lakṣmī. — 4) n. — a) Pl. die irdischen Räume. — b) Erdstoff. --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. Adj. — 1) (f. *ī*) Fürsten zukommend , ihnen gehörend , fürstlich , königlich. — 2) *n. Tabernaemontana coronaria [Rājan 10,145.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PWGScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Sanskrit-Wörterbuch in kürzerer Fassung Pārthiva (पार्थिव) in the Sanskrit language is related to the Prakrit word: [Patthiva](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/patthiva#prakrit). [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/sheth/): DDSA: Paia-sadda-mahannavo; a comprehensive Prakrit Hindi dictionary (S) Sanskrit, also spelled संस्कृतम् (*saṃskṛtam*), is an ancient language of India commonly seen as the grandmother of the Indo-European language family (even English!). Closely allied with Prakrit and Pali, Sanskrit is more exhaustive in both grammar and terms and has the most extensive collection of literature in the world, greatly surpassing its sister-languages Greek and Latin. ### Hindi dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Hindi glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) [Also spelled parthiv]:—(*a*) terrestrial, earthly; material; worldly, mundane; hence ~[*vatā*] (*nf*); ~[*vetara*] ultramundane, other-worldly; ~[*va śarīra*] material frame, mundane being. [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/caturvedi/): DDSA: A practical Hindi-English dictionary ... ### Kannada-English dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Kannada glossary Pārthiva (ಪಾರ್ಥಿವ):— 1) [adjective] of or related, the earth. 2) [adjective] related to ruling or ruler of the earth. 3) [adjective] of or limited to this world; temporal or secular; wordly. 4) [adjective] of man as a being who must eventually die (used chiefly in relation with human body). --- OR --- Pārthiva (ಪಾರ್ಥಿವ):— 1) [noun] that which belongs to or made of or generated from the earth (as plants). 2) [noun] a ruler; a king. 3) [noun] Śiva. 4) [noun] the earth-born, as a tree. 5) [noun] the sky. 6) [noun] the nineteenth year in the Hindu cycle of sixty years. 7) [noun] an earthen pot. 8) [noun] the physical body of a human being, animal or the physical structure of a plant. 9) [noun] the caste of warriors; military caste. [Source](https://alar.ink/glossary/kannada/english/%E0%B2%85): Alar: Kannada-English corpus Kannada is a Dravidian language (as opposed to the Indo-European language family) mainly spoken in the southwestern region of India. ### Nepali dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Nepali glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—adj. 1. earthly; terrestrial; 2. derived from earth; 3. physical; worldly; 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—n. 1. an earthen post; 2. king; prince; 3. inanimate object/thing; 4. mankind; [Source](https://unoes.net/en/): unoes: Nepali-English Dictionary Nepali is the primary language of the Nepalese people counting almost 20 million native speakers. The country of Nepal is situated in the Himalaya mountain range to the north of India. ## See also (Relevant definitions) Starts with ([+12](https://www.wisdomlib.org/index.php?type=search&division=glossary&mode=prefix&input=Parthiva)): [Parthiva-sharira](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiva-sharira), [Parthivabija](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivabija), [Parthivacchaya](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivacchaya), [Parthivacintamani](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivacintamani), [Parthivadhama](https://www.wisdomlib.

**Parthiv Ajay Patel** (born 9 March 1985) is a former Indian professional [cricketer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket), [wicketkeeper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wicketkeeper)-[batsman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batsman), who played for the [Indian national cricket team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_cricket_team).[2] He is a left-handed batsman and played for [Gujarat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat) in domestic cricket. Having lost a finger at the age of 6, he initially found it hard to keep wickets, but after enough practice, he got used to it.[3] When Patel played for the Indian team in 2002, he became the youngest wicket-keeper to represent a country in Tests. He was a part of the Indian squad which won the [2016 Asia Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Asia_Cup).

In December 2020, Patel announced his retirement from all forms of cricket.[4] After his retirement, Patel joined Mumbai Indians as a Talent Scout.[5] He is also now seen as a commentator in the Indian Premier League and International Matches too.

In November 2024, Patel was appointed as the assistant and batting coach of [Gujarat Titans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_Titans) for the upcoming season of the [Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Premier_League).[6]

## Domestic career

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=1)]

Patel led the Gujarat side in the [2016–17 Ranji Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Ranji_Trophy). Beating [Odisha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha_cricket_team) and [Jharkhand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jharkhand_cricket_team) in the quarterfinal and semifinal, the team reached the final for only the second time. In the final in January, they met defending champions [Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team) in Indore. Patel scored 90 in the first inning and 143 in the second and helped beat Gujarat to win its first Trophy.[7] Patel's 143 was the highest in a successful chase in a [Ranji Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranji_Trophy) final. The win also made Gujarat the first team and Patel the first captain to have won all three major titles in domestic cricket in India.[8]

In July 2018, he was named as the captain for India Green for the [2018–19 Duleep Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_Duleep_Trophy).[9] In October 2019, he was named as the captain of [India B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_B_cricket_team) for the [2019–20 Deodhar Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Deodhar_Trophy).[10]

### Indian Premier League

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=2)]

Patel was auctioned in the inaugural [Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Premier_League) (IPL) to [Chennai Super Kings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai_Super_Kings).[11] He used to be a regular in the team and opened with the former Australian opener [Matthew Hayden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Hayden). He did not keep wicket as the Indian wicketkeeper as captain [MS Dhoni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS_Dhoni) was in the team. For the fourth season, he was signed by [Kochi Tuskers Kerala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi_Tuskers_Kerala). On 16 May, it was announced that Parthiv will be leading the Kochi Tuskers Kerala for the rest of the [2011 Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Indian_Premier_League).[12] As a result of the termination of Kochi Tuskers franchise, Parthiv along with the other players from the franchise was once again auctioned for the [2012 Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Indian_Premier_League) season. He was picked by [Deccan Chargers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Chargers) for $1m During the 2012 IPL Trading Window. Parthiv was picked up by [Sunrisers Hyderabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunrisers_Hyderabad) in 2013 and by [Royal Challenger Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Challenger_Bangalore) in 2014. Patel was signed by [Mumbai Indians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai_Indians) for the 2015 IPL as an [opening batsmen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batting_order_(cricket)).[13]

In January 2018, he was bought by the [Royal Challengers Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Challengers_Bangalore) in the [2018 IPL auction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_Indian_Premier_League_personnel_changes).[14][15]

### Other franchise cricket

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=3)]

In 2022, Gujarat Giants selected him in the Legends League Cricket and gave him the captaincy in the 2023 Legends League Cricket season.[16]

## International career

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=4)]

Parthiv debuted in the year 2002 against England at Trent Bridge at 17 years and 153 days to become Test Cricket's youngest wicketkeeper. He had replaced the injured Ajay Ratra and eclipsed the record previously held by Pakistan's Hanif Mohammed (17 years and 300 days). He played out an hour in the match while batting and hence saved India from defeat. However, with the emergence of Dhoni and poor wicketkeeping, he was sidelined for a few matches in 2004.[17]

On 23 November 2016, Parthiv Patel was called up as a replacement for the regular wicket-keeper [Wriddhiman Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wriddhiman_Saha) who had a thigh strain, for the third Test (at [Mohali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Cricket_Association_IS_Bindra_Stadium)) of the [India-England home series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_cricket_team_in_India_in_2016%E2%80%9317).[18] He played his first Test in eight years, having missed 83 Test matches between appearances.[19]

Patel made his [ODI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Day_International) debut against [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_cricket_team) in January 2003.[20] He was selected in the Indian squad for the [2003 Cricket World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup) but did not play any games, with [Rahul Dravid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rahul_Dravid) being used as a makeshift wicket-keeper to allow the use of an extra batsman or bowler. With this policy in place, Patel only made intermittent appearances in ODIs, usually when Dravid was injured or being rested (in full or from wicket-keeping duties). He played 13 ODIs in a two-year span, and during an interrupted career managed only an average of 14.66 and a top-score of 28 and was dropped thereafter. Parthiv returned to the Indian team in 2010 in the 4th and 5th Odi vs New Zealand. He celebrated this moment by hitting two back to back half centuries. Later on he was called up for replacing injured Sachin Tendulkar in India tour South Africa .[21]

### Tour of West Indies 2011

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=5)]

With wicket-keeper captain [MS Dhoni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS_Dhoni) rested for the tour along with several seniors such as [Sachin Tendulkar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar), [Zaheer Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaheer_Khan), he was entrusted with the job of wicket-keeping in the tour along with Wriddhiman Saha. In the lone T20I match played in the tour, he made his T20I debut at the [Queen's Park Oval](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Park_Oval) at [Port-of-Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port-of-Spain). He opened the batting along with another left-handed debutante [Shikhar Dhawan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shikhar_Dhawan) and made a 26 from 20 balls. In the second ODI against West Indies he scored 56 [not out](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not_out).

### England tour of India 2016

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=6)]

With wicket-keeper [Wriddhiman Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wriddhiman_Saha) injured, Parthiv was called to test team duty for the third test in Mohali. He proved the selectors' decision was right with two good innings including an unbeaten 67 runs from 54 balls in the second innings which led India to victory.

### One of the Indian cricketers to play T20 match in 2005

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=7)]

Parthiv Patel, along with Robin Singh and Rohan Gavaskar played their first T20 match in 2005.[22] This was the early phase of t20 format. But the first Indian cricketer to play a t20 match was Dinesh Mongia.[23] He played his debut match in July 2004.

### Origin, Meaning, And History Of Parthiv

Parthiv is a masculine name rooted in Indian heritage. Originating from the Sanskrit term pārthiva, Parthiv translates to ‘related to earth’ or ‘earthly’. It can also carry other meanings such as ‘of the earth’, ‘as opposed to earth’, ‘son of the earth’, or ‘prince of the earth’. Pronounced as ‘pahr-thiv’, the name retains its original Sanskrit pronunciation, with an emphasis on the second syllable. Some cute nickname considerations for this name are Parth, Pari, Thiv, Paru, and Vitha.

### Parthiv On The US Popularity Chart

Societal influences, family traditions, latest trends, and timeless appeal are a few criteria that shape the choices of parents in naming their newest family members. In this section, we show you how the popularity of Parthiv has trended over the years in the US, in absolute numbers (per million) as well as in its ranking.

### Popularity Over Time

As per the SSA, data covering the name Parthiv spans 23 years, with the trend starting in 2000 and lasting until 2022. In 2008, the name reached its peak popularity, given to 12 in every million babies. The name did not find any takers in 2021.

### Rank Over Time

Parthiv's ranking has fluctuated over time, rising at intervals and then dipping, reflecting its varying popularity. In 2002, Parthiv was ranked 9140, it was 11881 in 2012 and 11930 in 2022.

### Parthiv’s Zodiac Sign As Per Western Astrology

Western astrology includes the construction of a horoscope based on the person’s exact time of birth and location to understand the positions of the planet, stars, and zodiac signs at that time. However, in popular culture, it is often narrowed down to the sun sign, which depends on the person’s birth date.There are 12 zodiac signs, each having dominant traits, planetary rulers, elemental connection, and more.

### Zodiac sign or Sun sign

The Earth’s orbit around the sun is divided into 12 zodiac signs covering 30-degree sectors. According to Western astrology, the zodiac or sun sign depends on the sun’s position in one of these sectors at the time of your birth. Starting from the sun’s position at the March equinox, the chart goes anti-clockwise from Aries, followed by Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces. These signs are ruled by planetary bodies - Mars, Venus, Mercury, Moon, Sun, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Furthermore, they are categorized into triplicities or elemental signs - fire, water, air, and earth - that govern their characteristics. Each of these zodiac signs features certain personality traits that may determine how a person presents themselves.

Vedic astrology, also called Jyotisha, provides deep insights into a person’s life based on celestial positions at birth. ## More About The Name Parthiv

The name Parthiva has its origins in Sanskrit, an ancient language of India. It is a combination of two words: "Parth" meaning "charioteer" or "prince" and "iva" meaning "like" or "belonging to." Therefore, Parthiva can be interpreted to mean "belonging to Parth" or "like a prince."There are not many famous personalities directly associated with the name Parthiva. However, there is a well-known Indian cricketer named Parthiv Patel, who has represented the Indian national team as a wicket-keeper.Regarding personality traits and facts, people with the name Parthiva are often described as confident, ambitious, and charismatic. They tend to have a natural leadership quality and enjoy taking charge of situations. Parthivas are often seen as highly responsible and reliable individuals who take their commitments seriously. They are also known for their determination and drive, which helps them to achieve their goals. Parthivas are generally assertive and courageous, and they have the ability to inspire others. Nakshatras are divided into three broad categories of 9 each as follows:1. Dev Gana: they're angel-like, subtle and refined.2. Manushya Gana: Manushya gana means human beings. they're just human and act accordingly.3. user_facing_answer.text:
Hello! PharmaMiku here! 🌟 While this isn't a medical question, I'll help explain what we know about the name Parthiv in a clear way! ✨

Name Meaning & Origin:
• Parthiv comes from Sanskrit "pārthiva" 
• It beautifully means "son of the earth" or "prince of earth"
• It's a Hindu/Indian boy's name with royal associations

Cultural Significance:
• Associated with positive qualities like:
  • Bravery
  • Leadership
  • Noble characteristics
• Connected to Hindu astrology:
  • Rashi (Zodiac): Kanya/Virgo
  • Nakshatra (Birth Star): Uttara Phalguni
  • Lucky number: 4

Famous Person:
• Parthiv Patel is the most well-known person with this name:
  • Former Indian cricket player (2002-2018)
  • Made history as youngest Test wicket-keeper at age 17
  • Now works as cricket commentator
  • Recently became assistant/batting coach for Gujarat Titans

Current Usage:
• Still used in India and Hindu communities
• Considered relatively uncommon (rank ~7322)
• Valued for its meaningful connection to earth and leadership

Learn More! 📚
For more information, you can check these sources:
• https://www.ask-oracle.com/baby-name/parthiv/
• https://mylofamily.com/parenting/babynames/meaning-of-parthiv-60619
• https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiva
• https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthiv_Patel
• https://hamariweb.com/names/hindu/hindi/boy/parthiv-meaning_31989/

Note: While I love sharing information, remember I'm an AI assistant. For specific cultural or religious interpretations, it's always best to consult with cultural experts or community members! 🌸

evidence.title: Parthiva, Pārthiva: 27 definitions
evidence.content: # Parthiva, Pārthiva: 27 definitions 1. [Introduction](#introduction) 2. [In Hinduism](#hinduism) Purana Natyashastra Jyotisha Ayurveda Shaktism 3. [In Buddhism](#buddhism) Tibetan Buddhism 4. [Languages](#language) Marathi Sanskrit Hindi Kannada Nepali 5. [See also](#relevant-definitions) ## Introduction: Parthiva means something in [Buddhism](https://www.wisdomlib.org/buddhism), Pali, [Hinduism](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism), Sanskrit, Marathi, Hindi. If you want to know the exact meaning, history, etymology or English translation of this term then check out the descriptions on this page. Add your comment or reference to a book if you want to contribute to this summary article. Alternative spellings of this word include [Parthiv](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiv). ## In Hinduism ### Purana and Itihasa (epic history) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Purana glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to “earthen”, representing the material of the liṅgas of the Aśvinidevas, according to the [Śivapurāṇa 2.1.12](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/shiva-purana-english/d/doc225980.html), where the Devas and Viṣṇu requested Viśvakarman for liṅgas for the achievement of the desires of all people:—“[...] at our bidding Viśvakarmā made liṅgas and gave them to the devas according to their status. [...] The Viśvedevas and the Vasus took silver liṅgas. O sage, the Aśvini devas took the brazen and earthen liṅgas (Pārthiva-liṅga). [...] Thus different kinds of liṅgas were given to them by Viśvakarmā which the devas and the celestial sages worship regularly. After giving the devas the various liṅgas from a desire for their benefit, Viṣṇu explained the mode of worship of Śiva to me, Brahmā”. 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to “clay”, representing a material for a Liṅga in one’s house (*geha*), according to the [Śivapurāṇa 2.1.13](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/shiva-purana-english/d/doc225981.html), while explaining the mode of worshipping Śiva:—“[...] after worshipping Śiva with sandal paste, saffron, incense, various lamps, and food-offerings of different sorts he shall bow down again. In the house the liṅga shall be made of clay (*pārthiva*), silver or any other metal or mercury. It shall be bowed to with devotion. If that is worshipped, all deities are worshipped. If the liṅga is made of clay it shall be installed duly”. [Source](https://archive.org/details/SivaPuranaJ.L.ShastriPart1): archive.org: Shiva Purana - English Translation 1a) Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—An Ārṣeya Pravara.* - [*](#text1_1) Matsya-purāṇa 196. 9. 1b) One of the three fires; it was so called when (1/4) of the night of Brahmā was remaining.* - [*](#text2_1) Vāyu-purāṇa 53. 5-7. 1c) Also Pavana; a kind of fire.* - [*](#text3_1) Brahmāṇḍa-purāṇa II. 24. 6. 1d) Of Kauśika gotra.* - [*](#text4_1) Vāyu-purāṇa 91. 98. [Source](http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PUIScan/2014/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: The Purana Index The Purana (पुराण, purāṇas) refers to Sanskrit literature preserving ancient India’s vast cultural history, including historical legends, religious ceremonies, various arts and sciences. The eighteen *mahapuranas* total over 400,000 *shlokas* (metrical couplets) and date to at least several centuries BCE. ### Natyashastra (theatrics and dramaturgy) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Natyashastra glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to a “king” (or, “lord of the earth”), whose beard (*śmaśru*) should be represented as *vicitra* (smartly done), according to [Nāṭyaśāstra chapter 23](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/the-natyashastra/d/doc210153.html). Providing the beard is a component of *nepathya* (costumes and make-up) and is to be done in accordance with the science of *āhāryābhinaya* (extraneous representation). [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Nāṭya-śāstra Natyashastra (नाट्यशास्त्र, *nāṭyaśāstra*) refers to both the ancient Indian tradition (*shastra*) of performing arts, (*natya*—theatrics, drama, dance, music), as well as the name of a Sanskrit work dealing with these subjects. It also teaches the rules for composing Dramatic plays (*nataka*), construction and performance of Theater, and Poetic works (*kavya*). ### Jyotisha (astronomy and astrology) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Jyotisha glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the “ruler” (of a kingdom), according to the [Bṛhatsaṃhitā (chapter 4)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita/d/doc226720.html), an encyclopedic Sanskrit work written by Varāhamihira mainly focusing on the science of ancient Indian astronomy astronomy (Jyotiṣa).—Accordingly, “If Jupiter should be eclipsed by the lunar disc the men of Gāndhāra, of Sauvīraka, of Sindhu and of Kīra (Kāśmīra) the rulers of the Draviḍa countries and Brāhmins as well as food grains and mountains will suffer for ten months. If Mars should be so eclipsed the rulers of Traigarta (Lāhora) and of Mālavā, with their fighting men in their cars, the chiefs of Kulinda, the rulers [i.e., *pārthiva*] of Śibi, of Audha, of Kuru (Delhi), of Matsya and of Śukti will suffer for six months”. 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the nineteenth of the sixty-year cycle of Jupiter, according to the [Bṛhatsaṃhitā (chapter 8)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita/d/doc226724.html).—Accordingly, “The first year of the fourth *yuga* is known as Citrabhānu; in it mankind will be happy. The second is known as Subhānu. In it mankind will be neither happy nor miserable; there will however be disease in the land but no deaths in consequence. The next year is known as Tāraṇa; in it there will be abundance of rain. The next is known as Pārthiva; in it crops with thrive well and mankind will be happy. The fifth year is known as Vyaya; in it amorous sensastions will prevail over the land”. [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/brihat-samhita): Wisdom Library: Brihat Samhita by Varahamihira Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the nineteenth [saṃvatsara (“jovian year)”](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/samvatsara) in Vedic astrology.—The native born in the ‘*samvatsara*’ of ‘*parthiva*’ performs the rites of his religion (with reverence), is well versed (learned) in the excellent *shastras*, is a perfected hand (skilled) in the field of arts, sensual or pleasure-loving and is the chief of his family. According with Jataka Parijata, the person born in the year *parthiva* (2005-2006 AD) will be a king unequalled for his prosperity and happiness. [Source](http://satva.blogspot.nl/2011/12/effects-of-samvatsaras.html): The effect of Samvatsaras: Satvargas Jyotisha (ज्योतिष, *jyotiṣa* or *jyotish*) refers to ‘astronomy’ or “Vedic astrology” and represents the fifth of the six Vedangas (additional sciences to be studied along with the Vedas). Jyotisha concerns itself with the study and prediction of the movements of celestial bodies, in order to calculate the auspicious time for rituals and ceremonies. ### Ayurveda (science of life) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Ayurveda glossary #### Nighantu (Synonyms and Characteristics of Drugs and technical terms) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) or Pārthivakṣetra refers to “earthen land” and represents one of the five classifications of [“land” (kṣetra)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/\), as defined in the first chapter (*ānūpādi-varga*) of the 13th-century Raj Nighantu or Rājanighaṇṭu (an Ayurvedic encyclopedia). Accordingly, “a *pārthiva* or earther land is usually four-cornered, symmetrical. t has yellowish story ground with bracelet like shining, rounded gravels and is full of yellow coloured dear heards and creepers with yellow flowers. It is a hard and raised land”. Substances (*dravya*) pertaining to Pārthiva-kṣetra are known as Pārthivadravya—Such *dravyas* alleviate diseases and enhance vitality. These are tasty and have steady effect. Brāhma is the deity of Pārthiva soil and substances. [Source](https://www.worldcat.org/title/raj-nighantu/oclc/826899360): WorldCat: Rāj nighaṇṭu #### Veterinary Medicine (The study and treatment of Animals) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to a “king”, according to the 15th century [Mātaṅgalīlā](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/matangalila#ayurveda) composed by Nīlakaṇṭha in 263 Sanskrit verses, dealing with elephantology in ancient India, focusing on the science of management and treatment of elephants.—[Cf. chapter 2, “on favorable marks”]: “6. With very glossy, shining eyes, and reddish trunk ends, with rod-like penis handsome with the beauty of mango shoots, radiant as red lotuses, with voice like the koil’s; such elephants, assuredly, are auspicious for kings (*pārthiva*) [*gajāḥ śubhakarāḥ khalu pārthivānām*]”. [Source](https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.217383): archive.org: The Elephant Lore of the Hindus #### Unclassified Ayurveda definitions 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—One of the category of substances that are of mineral origin like silver, gold, etc. 2) [pārthivam] The substance predominently made of prithvi mahabhuta [Source](https://www.gurumukhi.ru/ayurveda/dictionary.aspx): gurumukhi.ru: Ayurveda glossary of terms Āyurveda (आयुर्वेद, ayurveda) is a branch of Indian science dealing with medicine, herbalism, taxology, anatomy, surgery, alchemy and related topics. Traditional practice of Āyurveda in ancient India dates back to at least the first millenium BC. Literature is commonly written in Sanskrit using various poetic metres. ### Shaktism (Shakta philosophy) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Shaktism glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to the “whole earth”, according to the Manthānabhairavatantra, a vast sprawling work that belongs to a corpus of Tantric texts concerned with the worship of the goddess Kubjikā.—Accordingly, “If a conflagration without a fire (that starts it) begins suddenly in a village, the offering of beef into the Triangle with clarified butter a million times (brings about) great peace and that prevails over the whole earth [i.e., *pārthiva*]”. 2) Pārthivā (पार्थिवा) refers to one of the eight Yoginīs (*yoginī-aṣṭaka*) associated with Kāmākhya (corresponding to the eastern face of Bhairava), according to the Manthānabhairavatantra.—[...] The eight Yoginīs (*yoginyaṣṭaka*): Viśālā, Pārthivā, Yakṣī, Dhūrjaṭī, Viṣabhakṣaṇī, Sarvasiddhipradā, Tuṣṭi, Icchā, Siddhipradāyakī. [Source](https://books.google.com/books?id=2DhazgEACAAJ): Google Books: Manthanabhairavatantram Shakta (शाक्त, śākta) or Shaktism (śāktism) represents a tradition of Hinduism where the Goddess (Devi) is revered and worshipped. Shakta literature includes a range of scriptures, including various Agamas and Tantras, although its roots may be traced back to the Vedas. ## In Buddhism ### Tibetan Buddhism (Vajrayana or tantric Buddhism) [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Tibetan Buddhism glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to one of the “[Twenty-Five Kalkis](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/twenty-five-lineage-holders#tibetan-buddhism)” (Tibetan: *rigs ldan*) as well as the “[Thirty-two kings of Shambhala](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/thirty-two-kings-of-shambhala#tibetan-buddhism)”, according to the Tibetan oral recounting and written texts such as the Kalachakra Tantra (*kālacakratantra*), dealing with the Buddhist conception of the end of the world and time.—The Tibetan mythic land (the kingdom of Shambhala) is a parallel world invisible and inaccessible to common people which is closely related to the teaching about the Wheel of Time (*dus 'khor*). The seven Dharmarajas and twenty-five Kulikas [e.g., Pārthiva] are the traditional rulers of Shambhala, passing on the reign from father to son. Pārthiva is also known as Śrīpāla or Mahīpāla. He is known in Tibetan as (1) Sakyong (2) Rigden Sakyong [*rigs ldan sa skyong*] (3) [*sa skyong*] (4) [*sa bdag*] and in Mongolian as: Khaan Namninmiey. His traditional reign is considered to be from 1427 to 1527 CE. [Source](https://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Tibetan Buddhist Teachers, Deities and other Spiritual beings Pārthiva (पार्थिव) is the name of the [tree (vṛkṣa)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/vriksha) associated with [Kilakilārava](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/kilakilarava#tibetan-buddhism): the north-western [cremation ground (śmaśāna)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/shmashana#tibetan-buddhism) according to the Saṃvarodayatantra 17.38. The tree associated with the north-west is sometimes given as Arjuna or Dhanañjaya. As a part of this *sādhana*, the practicioner is to visualize a suitable dwelling place for the goddess inside the circle of protection which takes the form of eight cremation grounds. These trees (e.g., Pārthiva) that are associated with the cremation grounds are often equated with the eight *bodhi*-trees of the Buddhas (the current *buddha* plus the seven previous one). According to the Śmaśānavidhi each tree has a secondary tree (*upavṛkṣa*) that is depicted as lovely and covered in *vaṅga* flowers and fruit. In each tree lives a naked *rākṣasa* who is wrathful in form, who eats human flesh and who has the animal face or the mount of the *dikpati* in his cremation ground. [Source](http://www.wisdomlib.org): Wisdom Library: Vajrayogini Pārthiva (पार्थिव) (in Tibetan: *Sakyong*) (1427–1527 CE) refers to the sixteenth of the twenty-five Kalki kings (of Shambhala) who represents the holders of the Kalachakra (“wheel of time”) teachings of Buddha Shakyamuni.—The king Pārthiva is described as “holder of the cleaver that cuts the bonds of ignorance”. [Source](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tibetan_Buddhism): WikiPedia: Tibetan Buddhism Pārthiva (पार्थिव) refers to one of the eight trees (*vṛkṣa*) of the [Guṇacakra](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/gunacakra#tibetan-buddhism), according to the 10th century [Ḍākārṇava](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/dakarnava#buddhism) chapter 15. Accordingly, the *guṇacakra* refers to one of the four divisions of the [sahaja-puṭa (‘innate layer’)](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/sahaja#tibetan-buddhism), situated within the *padma* (lotus) in the middle of the [Herukamaṇḍala](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/herukamandala#buddhism). Pārthiva is associated with the charnel grounds (*śmaśāna*) named Kilikilārava; with the direction-guardian (*dikpāla*) named Vāyu; with the serpent king (*nāgendra*) named Śaṅkhapāla and with the cloud king (*meghendra*) named Caṇḍa. [Source](https://www.academia.edu/43250318/The_Structure_and_Meanings_of_the_Heruka_Ma%E1%B9%87%E1%B8%8Dala_in_the_Buddhist_%E1%B8%8C%C4%81k%C4%81r%E1%B9%87ava_Scriptural_Tradition): academia.edu: The Structure and Meanings of the Heruka Maṇḍala Tibetan Buddhism includes schools such as Nyingma, Kadampa, Kagyu and Gelug. Their primary canon of literature is divided in two broad categories: The Kangyur, which consists of Buddha’s words, and the Tengyur, which includes commentaries from various sources. Esotericism and tantra techniques (*vajrayāna*) are collected indepently. ## Languages of India and abroad ### Marathi-English dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Marathi glossary pārthiva (पार्थिव).—n S An earthen lingam made to use in worship. 2 m A king. --- OR --- pārthiva (पार्थिव).—a S Relating to earth, earthy or earthen. 2 Relating to the globe, terrene or terrestrial. [Source](http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/molesworth/): DDSA: The Molesworth Marathi and English Dictionary pārthiva (पार्थिव).—*n* An earthen lingam made to use in worship. *m* A king. *a* Relating to earth. Terrestrial. [Source](http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/vaze/): DDSA: The Aryabhusan school dictionary, Marathi-English Marathi is an Indo-European language having over 70 million native speakers people in (predominantly) Maharashtra India. Marathi, like many other Indo-Aryan languages, evolved from early forms of Prakrit, which itself is a subset of Sanskrit, one of the most ancient languages of the world. ### Sanskrit dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Sanskrit glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—*a.* (-vī *f.*) [पृथिव्याः ईश्वरः इदं वा अण् (pṛthivyāḥ īśvaraḥ idaṃ vā aṇ)] 1) Earthen, earthy, terrestrial, relating to the earth; यतो रजः पार्थिवमुज्जिहीते (yato rajaḥ pārthivamujjihīte) R.13.64. 2) Ruling the earth. 3) Princely, royal. -vaḥ 1 An inhabitant of the earth. 2) A king, sovereign; अथ तस्य विवाहकौतुकं ललितं बिभ्रत एव पार्थिवः (atha tasya vivāhakautukaṃ lalitaṃ bibhrata eva pārthivaḥ) R.8.1. 3) An earthen vessel. 4) The body. 5) The विकार (vikāra) of the earth; अयं जनो नाम चलन् पृथिव्यां यः पार्थिवः पार्थिव कस्य हेतोः (ayaṃ jano nāma calan pṛthivyāṃ yaḥ pārthivaḥ pārthiva kasya hetoḥ) Bhāgavata 5.12.5. 6) A गृह्याग्नि (gṛhyāgni) of the naming ceremony (*nāmakaraṇa*). -vam An earthy substance. -vā 1 A royal concubine. 2) Arsenic (see *nighaṇṭaratnākara*). [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/apte/): DDSA: The practical Sanskrit-English dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—mfn. (*-vaḥ-vā* or *vī-vaṃ*) 1. Earthen, made or derived from earth. 2. Ruling or possessing the earth. 3. Princely, royal. m. (*-vaḥ*) 1. A king, a prince. 2. An earthen vessel. 3. An inhabitant of the earth. f. (*-vī*) 1. A name of Sita. 2. An epithet of Lakshmi. E. *pṛthivī* the earth, *aṇ* aff. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/SHSScan/2014/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Shabda-Sagara Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—i. e. *pṛthivī + a*, I. adj., f. *vī*. 1. Terrestrial, Chr. 290, 3 = [Rigveda.] i. 64, 3 (vā for vāni). 2. Ruling or possessing the earth, Chr. 14, 17. 3. Royal, fit for kings or princes, Mahābhārata 5, 2187. Ii. m. 1. An inhabitant of the earth, [Rāmāyaṇa] 2, 25, 20. 2. A king, a prince. Iii. f. vī, Sītā. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/BENScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Benfey Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—1. [feminine] *ī* earthly, terrestrial; [masculine] inhabitant of the earth, lord of the earth, prince, king, warrior. Abstr. *tā*† [feminine], *tva*† [neuter] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव).—2. [feminine] *ī* royal, princely. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/CAEScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Cappeller Sanskrit-English Dictionary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—[from *pārthava*] mf(*ī* or *ā*; cf. [Pāṇini 4-1, 85], [vArttika] 2)n. ([from] *pṛthivī* f. of *pṛthu*) earthen, earthy, earthly, being in or relating to or coming from the earth, terrestrial, [Ṛg-veda] etc. etc. 2) [v.s. ...] mf(*ī*)n. (from m. below) fit for kings or princes, royal, princely, [Mahābhārata; Harivaṃśa] 3) [v.s. ...] m. an inhabitant of the earth, [Ṛg-veda; Atharva-veda] 4) [v.s. ...] a lord of the earth, king, prince, warrior, [Manu-smṛti; Mahābhārata] etc. 5) [v.s. ...] an earthen vessel, [cf. Lexicographers, esp. such as amarasiṃha, halāyudha, hemacandra, etc.] 6) [v.s. ...] a [particular] Agni, [Gṛhyāsaṃgraha] 7) [v.s. ...] the 19th (or 53rd) year in Jupiter’s cycle of 60 years, [Varāha-mihira] 8) [v.s. ...] ([plural]) Name of a family belonging to the Kauśikas, [Harivaṃśa] 9) [from *pārthava*] n. ([plural]) the regions of the earth, [Ṛg-veda] 10) [v.s. ...] an earthy substance, [Harivaṃśa] ([varia lectio] *thavi*), [Suśruta] 11) [v.s. ...] Tabernaemontana Coronaria, [cf. Lexicographers, esp. such as amarasiṃha, halāyudha, hemacandra, etc.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Monier-Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—*(vaḥ)* 1. *m.* A king; earthen vessel. *f.* (*vī*) *Sītā. a.* Earthen. [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/YATScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Yates Sanskrit-English Dictionary Pārthiva (पार्थिव):— --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. (von 1. *pārthiva* 2, b) adj. f. *ī* Fürsten zukommend, ihnen gehörend, fürstlich, königlich: *senā* [Mahābhārata 5, 2187.] *pravṛtti* [Sāvitryupākhyāna 6, 18.] *vartman* [Harivaṃśa 5462.] *pada* [5671.] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—1. 2) d) [Oxforder Handschriften 331,b,3 v. u.] --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. , *kṣatra* [Mahābhārata 5, 6069.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PWGScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Böhtlingk and Roth Grosses Petersburger Wörterbuch Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—1. — 1) Adj. (f. *ā* und *ī*) irdisch , auf oder in der Erde befindlich , auf die E. bezüglich , der E eigen , aus E. entstanden , irden. *vrata* n. die Weise der Erde. — 2) m. — a) Erdbewohner. — b) Fürst , Krieger , König. — c) ein best. Agni. — d) *ein irdenes Geschirr. — e) das 19te (53ste) Jahr im 60jährigen Jupitercyclus. — f) Metron. Pl. auch als Name eines zu den Kauśika gezählten Geschlechts [Harivaṃśa 1464.1771.] — 3) f. *pārthivī* Metron. — a) der Sitā. — b) *der Lakṣmī. — 4) n. — a) Pl. die irdischen Räume. — b) Erdstoff. --- OR --- Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—2. Adj. — 1) (f. *ī*) Fürsten zukommend , ihnen gehörend , fürstlich , königlich. — 2) *n. Tabernaemontana coronaria [Rājan 10,145.] [Source](https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PWGScan/2020/web/index.php): Cologne Digital Sanskrit Dictionaries: Sanskrit-Wörterbuch in kürzerer Fassung Pārthiva (पार्थिव) in the Sanskrit language is related to the Prakrit word: [Patthiva](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/patthiva#prakrit). [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/sheth/): DDSA: Paia-sadda-mahannavo; a comprehensive Prakrit Hindi dictionary (S) Sanskrit, also spelled संस्कृतम् (*saṃskṛtam*), is an ancient language of India commonly seen as the grandmother of the Indo-European language family (even English!). Closely allied with Prakrit and Pali, Sanskrit is more exhaustive in both grammar and terms and has the most extensive collection of literature in the world, greatly surpassing its sister-languages Greek and Latin. ### Hindi dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Hindi glossary Pārthiva (पार्थिव) [Also spelled parthiv]:—(*a*) terrestrial, earthly; material; worldly, mundane; hence ~[*vatā*] (*nf*); ~[*vetara*] ultramundane, other-worldly; ~[*va śarīra*] material frame, mundane being. [Source](https://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/caturvedi/): DDSA: A practical Hindi-English dictionary ... ### Kannada-English dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Kannada glossary Pārthiva (ಪಾರ್ಥಿವ):— 1) [adjective] of or related, the earth. 2) [adjective] related to ruling or ruler of the earth. 3) [adjective] of or limited to this world; temporal or secular; wordly. 4) [adjective] of man as a being who must eventually die (used chiefly in relation with human body). --- OR --- Pārthiva (ಪಾರ್ಥಿವ):— 1) [noun] that which belongs to or made of or generated from the earth (as plants). 2) [noun] a ruler; a king. 3) [noun] Śiva. 4) [noun] the earth-born, as a tree. 5) [noun] the sky. 6) [noun] the nineteenth year in the Hindu cycle of sixty years. 7) [noun] an earthen pot. 8) [noun] the physical body of a human being, animal or the physical structure of a plant. 9) [noun] the caste of warriors; military caste. [Source](https://alar.ink/glossary/kannada/english/%E0%B2%85): Alar: Kannada-English corpus Kannada is a Dravidian language (as opposed to the Indo-European language family) mainly spoken in the southwestern region of India. ### Nepali dictionary [«previous (P) next»] — Parthiva in Nepali glossary 1) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—adj. 1. earthly; terrestrial; 2. derived from earth; 3. physical; worldly; 2) Pārthiva (पार्थिव):—n. 1. an earthen post; 2. king; prince; 3. inanimate object/thing; 4. mankind; [Source](https://unoes.net/en/): unoes: Nepali-English Dictionary Nepali is the primary language of the Nepalese people counting almost 20 million native speakers. The country of Nepal is situated in the Himalaya mountain range to the north of India. ## See also (Relevant definitions) Starts with ([+12](https://www.wisdomlib.org/index.php?type=search&division=glossary&mode=prefix&input=Parthiva)): [Parthiva-sharira](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthiva-sharira), [Parthivabija](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivabija), [Parthivacchaya](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivacchaya), [Parthivacintamani](https://www.wisdomlib.org/definition/parthivacintamani), [Parthivadhama](https://www.wisdomlib.

**Parthiv Ajay Patel** (born 9 March 1985) is a former Indian professional [cricketer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket), [wicketkeeper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wicketkeeper)-[batsman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batsman), who played for the [Indian national cricket team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_cricket_team).[2] He is a left-handed batsman and played for [Gujarat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat) in domestic cricket. Having lost a finger at the age of 6, he initially found it hard to keep wickets, but after enough practice, he got used to it.[3] When Patel played for the Indian team in 2002, he became the youngest wicket-keeper to represent a country in Tests. He was a part of the Indian squad which won the [2016 Asia Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Asia_Cup).

In December 2020, Patel announced his retirement from all forms of cricket.[4] After his retirement, Patel joined Mumbai Indians as a Talent Scout.[5] He is also now seen as a commentator in the Indian Premier League and International Matches too.

In November 2024, Patel was appointed as the assistant and batting coach of [Gujarat Titans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_Titans) for the upcoming season of the [Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Premier_League).[6]

## Domestic career

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=1)]

Patel led the Gujarat side in the [2016–17 Ranji Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Ranji_Trophy). Beating [Odisha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha_cricket_team) and [Jharkhand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jharkhand_cricket_team) in the quarterfinal and semifinal, the team reached the final for only the second time. In the final in January, they met defending champions [Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team) in Indore. Patel scored 90 in the first inning and 143 in the second and helped beat Gujarat to win its first Trophy.[7] Patel's 143 was the highest in a successful chase in a [Ranji Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranji_Trophy) final. The win also made Gujarat the first team and Patel the first captain to have won all three major titles in domestic cricket in India.[8]

In July 2018, he was named as the captain for India Green for the [2018–19 Duleep Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_Duleep_Trophy).[9] In October 2019, he was named as the captain of [India B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_B_cricket_team) for the [2019–20 Deodhar Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Deodhar_Trophy).[10]

### Indian Premier League

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=2)]

Patel was auctioned in the inaugural [Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Premier_League) (IPL) to [Chennai Super Kings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai_Super_Kings).[11] He used to be a regular in the team and opened with the former Australian opener [Matthew Hayden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Hayden). He did not keep wicket as the Indian wicketkeeper as captain [MS Dhoni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS_Dhoni) was in the team. For the fourth season, he was signed by [Kochi Tuskers Kerala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi_Tuskers_Kerala). On 16 May, it was announced that Parthiv will be leading the Kochi Tuskers Kerala for the rest of the [2011 Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Indian_Premier_League).[12] As a result of the termination of Kochi Tuskers franchise, Parthiv along with the other players from the franchise was once again auctioned for the [2012 Indian Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Indian_Premier_League) season. He was picked by [Deccan Chargers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Chargers) for $1m During the 2012 IPL Trading Window. Parthiv was picked up by [Sunrisers Hyderabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunrisers_Hyderabad) in 2013 and by [Royal Challenger Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Challenger_Bangalore) in 2014. Patel was signed by [Mumbai Indians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai_Indians) for the 2015 IPL as an [opening batsmen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batting_order_(cricket)).[13]

In January 2018, he was bought by the [Royal Challengers Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Challengers_Bangalore) in the [2018 IPL auction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_Indian_Premier_League_personnel_changes).[14][15]

### Other franchise cricket

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=3)]

In 2022, Gujarat Giants selected him in the Legends League Cricket and gave him the captaincy in the 2023 Legends League Cricket season.[16]

## International career

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=4)]

Parthiv debuted in the year 2002 against England at Trent Bridge at 17 years and 153 days to become Test Cricket's youngest wicketkeeper. He had replaced the injured Ajay Ratra and eclipsed the record previously held by Pakistan's Hanif Mohammed (17 years and 300 days). He played out an hour in the match while batting and hence saved India from defeat. However, with the emergence of Dhoni and poor wicketkeeping, he was sidelined for a few matches in 2004.[17]

On 23 November 2016, Parthiv Patel was called up as a replacement for the regular wicket-keeper [Wriddhiman Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wriddhiman_Saha) who had a thigh strain, for the third Test (at [Mohali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Cricket_Association_IS_Bindra_Stadium)) of the [India-England home series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_cricket_team_in_India_in_2016%E2%80%9317).[18] He played his first Test in eight years, having missed 83 Test matches between appearances.[19]

Patel made his [ODI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Day_International) debut against [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_cricket_team) in January 2003.[20] He was selected in the Indian squad for the [2003 Cricket World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup) but did not play any games, with [Rahul Dravid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rahul_Dravid) being used as a makeshift wicket-keeper to allow the use of an extra batsman or bowler. With this policy in place, Patel only made intermittent appearances in ODIs, usually when Dravid was injured or being rested (in full or from wicket-keeping duties). He played 13 ODIs in a two-year span, and during an interrupted career managed only an average of 14.66 and a top-score of 28 and was dropped thereafter. Parthiv returned to the Indian team in 2010 in the 4th and 5th Odi vs New Zealand. He celebrated this moment by hitting two back to back half centuries. Later on he was called up for replacing injured Sachin Tendulkar in India tour South Africa .[21]

### Tour of West Indies 2011

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=5)]

With wicket-keeper captain [MS Dhoni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS_Dhoni) rested for the tour along with several seniors such as [Sachin Tendulkar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar), [Zaheer Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaheer_Khan), he was entrusted with the job of wicket-keeping in the tour along with Wriddhiman Saha. In the lone T20I match played in the tour, he made his T20I debut at the [Queen's Park Oval](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Park_Oval) at [Port-of-Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port-of-Spain). He opened the batting along with another left-handed debutante [Shikhar Dhawan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shikhar_Dhawan) and made a 26 from 20 balls. In the second ODI against West Indies he scored 56 [not out](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not_out).

### England tour of India 2016

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=6)]

With wicket-keeper [Wriddhiman Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wriddhiman_Saha) injured, Parthiv was called to test team duty for the third test in Mohali. He proved the selectors' decision was right with two good innings including an unbeaten 67 runs from 54 balls in the second innings which led India to victory.

### One of the Indian cricketers to play T20 match in 2005

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Parthiv_Patel&action=edit&section=7)]

Parthiv Patel, along with Robin Singh and Rohan Gavaskar played their first T20 match in 2005.[22] This was the early phase of t20 format. But the first Indian cricketer to play a t20 match was Dinesh Mongia.[23] He played his debut match in July 2004.

### Origin, Meaning, And History Of Parthiv

Parthiv is a masculine name rooted in Indian heritage. Originating from the Sanskrit term pārthiva, Parthiv translates to ‘related to earth’ or ‘earthly’. It can also carry other meanings such as ‘of the earth’, ‘as opposed to earth’, ‘son of the earth’, or ‘prince of the earth’. Pronounced as ‘pahr-thiv’, the name retains its original Sanskrit pronunciation, with an emphasis on the second syllable. Some cute nickname considerations for this name are Parth, Pari, Thiv, Paru, and Vitha.

### Parthiv On The US Popularity Chart

Societal influences, family traditions, latest trends, and timeless appeal are a few criteria that shape the choices of parents in naming their newest family members. In this section, we show you how the popularity of Parthiv has trended over the years in the US, in absolute numbers (per million) as well as in its ranking.

### Popularity Over Time

As per the SSA, data covering the name Parthiv spans 23 years, with the trend starting in 2000 and lasting until 2022. In 2008, the name reached its peak popularity, given to 12 in every million babies. The name did not find any takers in 2021.

### Rank Over Time

Parthiv's ranking has fluctuated over time, rising at intervals and then dipping, reflecting its varying popularity. In 2002, Parthiv was ranked 9140, it was 11881 in 2012 and 11930 in 2022.

### Parthiv’s Zodiac Sign As Per Western Astrology

Western astrology includes the construction of a horoscope based on the person’s exact time of birth and location to understand the positions of the planet, stars, and zodiac signs at that time. However, in popular culture, it is often narrowed down to the sun sign, which depends on the person’s birth date.There are 12 zodiac signs, each having dominant traits, planetary rulers, elemental connection, and more.

### Zodiac sign or Sun sign

The Earth’s orbit around the sun is divided into 12 zodiac signs covering 30-degree sectors. According to Western astrology, the zodiac or sun sign depends on the sun’s position in one of these sectors at the time of your birth. Starting from the sun’s position at the March equinox, the chart goes anti-clockwise from Aries, followed by Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces. These signs are ruled by planetary bodies - Mars, Venus, Mercury, Moon, Sun, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Furthermore, they are categorized into triplicities or elemental signs - fire, water, air, and earth - that govern their characteristics. Each of these zodiac signs features certain personality traits that may determine how a person presents themselves.

### Parthiv’s Zodiac Sign And Birth Star As Per Vedic Astrology

Vedic astrology, also called Jyotisha, provides deep insights into a person’s life based on celestial positions at birth. Rashi and nakshatra, which are an integral part of Jyotisha, are believed to influence an individual’s personality and life events. The following sections give you rashi-related information, such as the associated letters, elements, ruling body, quality, and nakshatra for the name Parthiv. Another important aspect of Vedic Astrology is the nakshatras, the lunar constellations or star clusters that the Moon occupies during a person's birth. ## More About The Name Parthiv

The name Parthiva has its origins in Sanskrit, an ancient language of India. It is a combination of two words: "Parth" meaning "charioteer" or "prince" and "iva" meaning "like" or "belonging to." Therefore, Parthiva can be interpreted to mean "belonging to Parth" or "like a prince."There are not many famous personalities directly associated with the name Parthiva. However, there is a well-known Indian cricketer named Parthiv Patel, who has represented the Indian national team as a wicket-keeper.Regarding personality traits and facts, people with the name Parthiva are often described as confident, ambitious, and charismatic. They tend to have a natural leadership quality and enjoy taking charge of situations. Parthivas are often seen as highly responsible and reliable individuals who take their commitments seriously. They are also known for their determination and drive, which helps them to achieve their goals. Parthivas are generally assertive and courageous, and they have the ability to inspire others. Nakshatra means Star map in which Naksha means a map and Tara means a star. There are 27 Nakshatras/Stars and its name given to the constellation of the Moon because the Moon resides in each of the constellations for at some point. Nakshatras are divided into three broad categories of 9 each as follows:1. Dev Gana: they're angel-like, subtle and refined.2. Manushya Gana: Manushya gana means human beings. they're just human and act accordingly.3.
